headline: Two-Ingredient Air Fryer Bagels
description: Two-ingredient dough is used to make these easy, delicious air fryer bagels.
name: Two-Ingredient Air Fryer Bagels

recipeInstructions.text: Using a fork, mix flour and Greek yogurt together in a medium bowl until a crumbly dough forms. If mixture is too thick, add a little more yogurt or if too sticky, add a bit more flour.

Transfer dough to a lightly floured work surface, and knead until smooth, 5 to 7 minutes. Divide the dough evenly into 4 balls, rolling and stretching each into 3/4-inch thick ropes that are about 8- to 9-inches long. Connect both ends, pinching and sealing to form a bagel. Brush with egg white, and sprinkle with bagel seasoning.
Preheat an air fryer to 280 degrees F (137 degrees C). Line the fryer basket with a parchment liner or spray lightly with cooking spray.
Place the bagels in the basket, and cook until golden brown, 15 to 16 minutes. Do not crowd the basket, and cook in two batches if your air fryer is small.
Remove to a rack, and cool for about 15 minutes before slicing.

review.reviewBody: Deliciously simple. Made more of rounded bagels. But definitely going to do it again. Put chili powder and granulated garlic on top.
I made just as written. Love, love, love! So simple & quick.
More like the consistency of a biscuit but they have a good flavor. Easy to make and the directions were on point. I’m going to toast one and see how it tastes then. I’ll make them again :)
Made them exactly as written. Interesting, sort of doughy rolls but NOT a bagel by any means. A lot less work than a real bagel so if you just want a chewy,easy roll they're fine.

Really good, easy to make bagels. They tasted a little more of biscuits than bagels but the texture was right on and they were very tasty. Covered with some everything bagel seasoning. I used white lily self rising flour and I'm not sure if that contributed to the taste being more biscuit like. Would make again.

These bagels are pretty easy to make. Mine didn't rise like the ones in the other reviews, I may have worked the dough too much. The first batch I did at 280 degrees per the recipe, but I thought the color was too light. I increased the temp to 290 for the next batch and they were lightly browned, could have maybe gone up to 300 degrees. They turned out pretty good with the everything bagel seasoning.
These are easy to whip up, tender and delicious. I used everything seasoning for this round. Will make again!

These may not taste exactly like bagels, but they do make a delicious breakfast. I was thinking the interior would be soft and crumbly (like a biscuit), but it wasn’t. These delivered a firm “bagel” but weren’t dry at all. I wanted to try the two different methods of shaping. I rolled the first two in a ball and poked my thumb through the middle to get the bagel shape. The last two were made from ropes and shaped in a circle. I should have made my rope shorter so that the hole in the middle would be smaller. This method is actually easiest. I expected the shaping to be labor intensive, but it wasn’t. I would definitely make these again.

I really like how easy these were to make! I ended up letting my dough rest for 15 minutes while cleaning the kitchen, then formed my bagels and let them rest again while the air fryer preheated. When I pulled out the bagels from the initial baking they seemed pale and bit underdone, but once they rested and were sliced and toasted they were great! My husband said the final bagels were a bit too salty so I might ease up on the everything bagel seasoning next time, but obviously that can be adjusted to each baker's preference. I definitely could taste a tangy flavor from the greek yogurt but it gave almost a sourdough taste which I think works well. would definitely make these again!
